ML Design Choices

hypothesis class + loss function + optimizer + hyperparameters + features + ……

  • hypothesis class (aka model family):

    linear functions, polynomial functions, decision tree ……

    From which the ML black-box must pick one to fit the data.

  • loss function:

    MSE,

    evaluate the quality of the fit.

  • optimizer:

    how to search the function that best fits the data.

Linear Regression

Linear Functions

fβ(x)=β⊤x=[β1⋯βd][x1⋮xd]=β1x1+⋯+βdxd

x∈Rd is called an input or features or covariates.

$ \beta \in \mathbb{R}^d$ is called the parameters or parameter vector.

y^=fβ(x) is called predicted (label) or output or response.

Loss Function

Loss function is a scalar function. A good loss function should expresses all the performance metrice you cared about and is convenient for machine learning to compute.

Mean Squared Error (MSE)

L(β;Z)=1n∑i=1n(yi−β⊤xi)2

Linear Regression Problem

  • Input: Dataset Z={(x1,y1), ... ,(xn,yn)}, where xi∈Rd and $ y_i \in \mathbb{R}$.

  • Compute:

    β^(Z)=arg⁡minβ∈RdL(β;Z)=arg⁡minβ∈Rd1n∑i=1n(yi−β⊤xi)2

    Finding an appropriate β is also a process of finding an appropriate function in the hypothesis class.

  • Output: A linear function fβ^(Z)(x)=β^(Z)Tx such that yi≈β^(Z)Txi.

From another point, we are trying to find out a function fβ, which can approximate the ‘true function’ f∗ that produces the real date and is unknown, in the model family F.

most of time, f∗ not in our model family F

Linear Regression With Feature Maps

Feature Maps

In order to enable the linear model to fit nonlinear data, the feature map is introduced.

ϕ:x→Rd′ means transforming the original input x (from the space X with dimentsion d) into a new feature vector ϕ(x) (with a dimension of d′). d and d′ can be different.

Increasing d′ means increasing model’s capacity and it also means decreasing bias but increasing variance. Thus, we need to construct Φ to balance trade-off between bias and variance.

There is a rule of thumb: n=d′logd′, n is number of samples.

Then F={fβ(x)=βTϕ(x)}. And $L(\beta; Z) = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \left( y_i - \beta^{\top} \phi(x_i) \right)^2 $

  • For example:

    • x∈R1

      Assume the true function is y=2x2+3x+5.

      Define the feature map: ϕ(x)=[1xx2]

      Apply the linear model to the mapped features: fβ(x)=β⊤ϕ(x)=β0⋅1+β1⋅x+β2⋅x2

      Loss function: L(β;Z)=1n∑i=1n(yi−(β0+β1xi+β2xi2))2

      By minimizing the loss function, the following can be obtained: β^=[532]

    • x∈Rn n=2

      $x = \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \ x_2 \end{bmatrix} $

      The true function is y=3x12+2x1x2+5x2+4

      ϕ(x)=[1x1x2x12x1x2]

      fβ(x)=β⊤ϕ(x)=β0⋅1+β1⋅x1+β2⋅x2+β3⋅x12+β4⋅x1x2

      L(β;Z)=1n∑i=1n(yi−(β0+β1xi1+β2xi2+β3xi12+β4xi1xi2))2

      β^=[40532]

    • other examples

      • ϕ(x)=[1 x1 x2 ... xd]T

        The first element 1 is for the intercept.

        In this way, Rd→Rd+1

      • x∈{’high school’,"college","master"}. ϕ(x) maps to 1,2,3

      • x is the message such as “the food was good”. ϕ(x) maps to [1("good"∈x)  1("bad"∈x)  ...]T

Algorithm for Non-linear Regression

  1. Select an appropriate feature map:

    ϕ(x)=[ϕ1(x)...ϕd′(x)]

    The number of features should be constrained, because more features means more expressive hypothesis space. In this way, the model will be overfitting.

  2. Compute ϕi=ϕ(xi) for each xi in Z.

  3. Run linear regression with Z′={(ϕ1,y1),...,(ϕn,yn)}

Training/Test Split

Randomly shuffle data first, and then split data Z into Ztrain and Ztest. Run linear regression with Ztrain to obtain β^(Ztrain).

Ltrain=L(β^(Ztrain);Ztrain)Ltest=L(β^(Ztrain);Ztest)

For overfitting: Ltrain is small and Ltest is large. For underfitting, they both are pretty large.

The reason why it was okay to just randomly sample Ztrain and Ztest from the same Z is Independent and Identically Distributed(i.i.d). That is a strong assumption.

Bias and Variance: way to assess overfitting and underfitting

Consider you have k training datasets drawn from the same i.i.d over the data, and each time fit your model {fβ^1:k} to it. That is to say, you have k different functions.

  • Variance: how much do those fitted functions differ amongst each other, on average?

  • Bias: how much does the average of all those fitted functions deviate from the “true” function over the data distribution?

upper right means overfitting, left lower means underfitting

That also can be applied to the real functions.

Low Variance means model is not sensitive to noises. Then, this model is good for fewer/worse data. Low Bias means model has a high capacity. Then, this model is good for more/better data.

Effective Bias/Variance Under Varying Dataset Sizes

When the training dataset becomes larger, what will happen to Bias and Variance?

  • Bias: Bias will not be impacted by the size of trainning dataset. The essence of bias lies in the limitations of the expression in the hypothesis space. Increasing the amount of data can make the model get closer to the optimal model within the hypothesis space, but it can not break through the limitation of the space.

  • Variance: Variance will be lower. Increasing data will provide a stronger control to the functions.

When expanding the hypothesis class (similar to adding more dimensions to the features), what will happen to Bias and Variance?

  • Bias: Expanding the hypothesis class means the model has higher capacity. That is to say, Bias will be lower.

  • Variance: Bias being lower means Variance being higher.

Regularization: way to fix underfitting and overfitting

  • Solutions to fix underfitting and overfitting

    • Improve the trainning dataset -> collect more data.
    • Choose the right model family -> not too simple, not too complex.
    • Choose the right loss function -> MSE + a term which can control the fit complexity.

Linear regression with L2 regularization:

L(β;Z)=1n∑i=1n(yi−βTxi)2+λ∥β∥22=1n∑i=1n(yi−βTxi)2+λ∑j=1dβj2

λ is a hyperparameter, λ>=0, and λ should between [10−3,103]

If using intercept term ϕ(x)=[1,x1,…,xn]T, no penalty on the bias parameter β1=1:

L(β;Z)==1n∑i=1n(yi−βTxi)2+λ∑j=2dβj2

sum from j=2

skipping the penalty on the bias term ensures regularization focuses on taming feature-related complexity (to prevent overfitting) without harming the model’s ability to fit the data’s overall trend (to prevent underfitting).

Intuition on L2 Regularization

Consider a feature map with d=10 features [x1,...,xd]. Suppose during linear regression we forced βj=0 for all j>5. This is exactly equal to choosing a smaller-capacity hypothesis class, induced by the smaller feature maps with d=5.

Thus a large λ will pull coefficients towards 0, which let the function have a low capacity.

L2 regularized regression amounts to preferring smaller weights according to Gaussian Probability Density Function (Gaussian pdf).

When the λ becomes larger, the plot of Gaussian pdf becomes much slimmer.

At the “full loss” point, the “pull force of the fitted data” and the “pull force of the simplified weights” counterbalance each other, achieving stability. When λ becomes larger, the “pull force of the simplified weights” becomes larger.

ℹ️ Note
For the new parameter βnew∗=minβLnew(β;Z) (Lnew(β;Z)=L(β;Z)+λR(β)), their corresponding value of L(β;Z) would be larger than before regularization.

Since, L(β;Z) before regularization is the smallest. βnew∗ will let model be more generalize. Thus, L(βnew∗;Z) will be larger than L(βold∗;Z) (βold∗=minβLold(β;Z), Lold(β;Z)=L(β;Z)).

Cross-Validation for Hyperparameter Tuning / Model Selection

Hyperparameter Tuning

Naive strategy to select λ is by trying a few different candidates λi and choose the one that minimizes the test loss. It often make sense to sample uniformly in log-space e.g. 10−3,10−2,10−1,1,101,102,103.

But if we directly tune λ on test dataset, it will contaminate the test dataset. Because test set MSE is meant to be an unbiased noisy estimate of true generalization MSE. But tuning λ on test set leaks test set info into model. Test set error gets biased to be lower than true generalization error.

overfitting of hyperparameters on test set

Validation Set

The solution for the problem above is Validation set.

  • Now, the dataset is split into three parts:

    • Training set: used to find the optimal parameters.
    • Validation set: used to find the optimal λ.
    • Testing set: used to get the generalization ability of the model.
Cross Validation

  • Basic algorithm

    1. Split Z into Ztrian, Zval and Ztest.
    2. For t∈{1,…,h} hyperparameter choices:
      • Run linear regression with Ztrain and λt to obtain β^(Ztrain,λt).
      • Evaluate validation loss Lvalt=L(β^(Ztrain,λt),Zval)
    3. Get the best λt
      • Choose t′=arg⁡mintLvalt with lowest validation loss.
      • Re-run linear regression with Ztrain (actually, this Ztrain is not similar with the above Ztrain, this Ztrain means Ztrain+Zvali) and λt′ to obtain β^(Ztrain,λt).

  • k-fold algorithm (Z is small)

    Assuming k=3, with each λt, we can get the validation loss on each Zval. Then, the mean of those loss is the loss of λt.

    Lvalt=L(β^(Ztrain1,λt),Zval1)+L(β^(Ztrain2,λt),Zval2)+L(β^(Ztrain3,λt),Zval3)3

    Other steps is similar with basic algorithm.

    As k becomes bigger, model selection becomes more accurate, but algorithm becomes more computationally expensive.

Other Performance Metrics

Every loss function is a performance metric, but not every performance metric is a convenient loss function.

  • Mean Absolute Error:

    1n∑i=1n|yi^−yi|

  • Mean Relative Error:

    1n∑i=1n|yi^−yi||yi|

  • R2 Score:

    1−MSELabel Variance

    Higher is better, R2=1 is perfect.

    Variance=1n∑i=1N(xi−μ)2

  • Pearson Correlation:

    1n∑i=1n(yi^−μ^)(yi−μ)σ^σ

  • Rank-order correlation:

For any performance measure, always compare against some simple “common sense” baselines. The baselines can be: Randomly predicting some sample from the training label; Predicting the mean/median of the training labels; Any other handcoded functions

Optimizing the MSE Loss

Y=XβY=[y1⋮yn]   X=[x1…x1,d⋮⋱⋮xn,1…xn,d]   β=[β1⋮βd]

Then, the Loss function is:

L(β;Z)=1n∑i=1n(yi−βTxi)2=1n∥Y−Xβ∥22

Closed-Form Solution

The goal is :

∇βL(β^;Z)=0

Then,

∇βL(β;Z)=∇β1n∥Y−Xβ∥22=∇β1n(Y−Xβ)T(Y−Xβ)

Let A=(Y−Xβ), then

∇βL(β;Z)=∇β1nATA

Thus, L=f(A), A=g(β).

According to the the chain rule of scalars against vectors:

∇βL(β;Z)=(∇Af)T∇βA

For ∇Af, according to the derivative rule of a scalar with respect to a vector:

if f=aTa, then ∇af=2a,where a is a vector

Thus,

∇Af=2nA

For ∇βA, we can get that:

∇βA=∇β(Y−Xβ)=−X

So,

∇βL(β;Z)=(2nA)T(−X)=2nAT(−X)=−2nX(Y−Xβ)T

Finally,

∇βL(β;Z)=−2nXTY+2nXTXβ

💡 Tip
It also can be written as:

∇βL(β;Z)=1n∑i=1n2(yi−βTxi)xi

For a single training data sample:

2n(yi−βTxi)xi

i.e., the current error yi−βTxi times the feature vector xi.

Thus, Large error samples induce large change to β. Large feature values induce large change to β.

Set∇βL(β^;Z)=0, we have:

XTXβ^=XTY

Assume XTX is invertible, we have:

β^(Z)=(XTX)−1XTY

ℹ️ Note
Solution is unique only when XTX is invertible (full rank).

  • when feature dimension d is bigger than data examples n.

    • Remove features or collect more data → n≥d

  • when some feature is a linear combination of others.

    • Remove linearly dependent features.
    • Use L2 regularization.

Example:

[1122][β^1β^2]=[24]

In this case, any β^2=2−β^1 is a solution

  • Disadvantages:

    • Computing (XTX)−1 is O(d3). (O(nd2) for computing XTX, O(d3) for inverse).
    • Numerical accuracy issues due to “ill-conditioning”

Gradient Descent

  • Global search: randomly try (βt independent of βt−1) → very unstructured, taking a long time.

  • Local search: βt is computed based on βt−1.

βt+1=βt−α∗∇βL(βt;Z)

α is learning rate (hyperparameter).

The gradient is the direction along which L(β;Z) changes most quickly as a function of β.

For linear regression loss, it is a convex function, so there is no local minima.

The gradient descent will continually repeat until ∥βt+1−βt∥≤ϵ (convergence).

  • Learning Rate α :

    If α is too small, L(β;Z) decease slowly. If α is too large, L(β;Z) stagnates or even increase.

    One heuristic(启发方法) is to decrease α over time to force β to converge.

  • Time complexity:

    O(nd) for Xβ, O(n) for (Xβ−Y), O(nd) for left-multiplying by XT, O(d) for subtracting from βt.

    With T times iteration, the overall time complexity is O(ndT).

Batch Gradient Descent & Stochastic Gradient Descent

  • Batch Gradient Descent (BGD)

    βj←βj−α∑i=1n2(yi−β⊤xi)xi∀d

    Repeat it for T times, the overall time complexity is O(ndT)

  • Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD)

    • Initialize β.

    • Randomly shuffle dataset. (To reduce bias and ensure each epoch provides a different, more representative sampling of the data.)

    • Repeat T′ times until convergence{

      For i=1…n, do

      βj←βj−α2(yi−β⊤xi)xi∀d

      }

    The overall time complexity is O(dT′n). (Repeat T′n times, O(d) for each update)

Normally, SGD is faster than BGD because T′n≈10T.

Optimizing Regularized Linear Regression

L2-regularized Linear Regression

The loss is:

L(β;Z)=1n∑i=1n(yi−β⊤xi)2+λ∑j=1dβj2=1n∥Y−Xβ∥22+λ∥β∥22

The gradient is:

∇βL(β;Z)=−2nX⊤Y+2nX⊤Xβ+2λβ

  • Closed form

    Set gradient to be zero, then we can get the optimal parameter:

    β^(Z)=(X⊤X+nλI)−1X⊤Y

  • Gradient Descent

    The extra term λβ in the gradient is often interpreted as “weight decay”. At each update, it decays β→β(1−2αλ).

Feature Preprocessing And Selection

A data can be measured in centimeters, while it also can be measured in millimeters. Apart from the unit (or to say scaling), there is no different between them.

We would like our ML algorithm to not get affected in any substantive / meaningful way by such simple scaling. -> Scale invariance

  • For unregularized linear regression

    It is scale invariant. With x is multiplied by k, beta is reduced by 1n.

  • For regularized linear regression

    The regularized term depends directly on the parameter scale.

Feature Standardization

To let solve the problem above, we can use feature standardization, which will rescale all features (except x1=1) to zero mean and unit variance.

xi,j←xi,j−μjtrainσjtrain

📘 Important
For testing dataset, each sample should be scaled by the μjtrain and σjtrain.

Feature map

Such as converting all data to be numeric type.

Feature Selection

To control the size of the hypothesis class

  • Select features most correlated with label

  • Get rid of features that are heavily correlated with each other, to reduce redundancy.

Handling Missing Values

L1 Regularization (LASSO) And Automatic Feature Selection

  • L0 Regularization

    ∥β∥0=|{j|βj=0}|

    The number of non-zero component.

    Automatic feature selsection

    • Challenge: ∥β∥0 is not differentiable.

      If β changes from [0,0] to [0.00000001,0], ∥β∥0 changes from 0 to 1. That means a slight change of β can cause a huge change in ∥β∥0. Thus we introduce L1 regularization.

  • L1 Regularization

    ∥β∥1=λ∑j=1d|βj|

    ❗ Caution
    Do not regularize the constant term (intercept).

    Solutions aren’t always sparse, but the “corners” on the axes in green contours makes this probable for larger λ. As λ becomes larger, β2 has higher probability to be zero. In practice, if |βj|≤μ, just set it to zero. μ is threshold.

    💡 Tip
    Q: when would we get sparse solutions on the positive β1 axis? (how would the data fit contours have to change for this?)

    A: Todo

    L1 regularization induces a Laplacian prior on the values of β. Thus, more parameters drawn to 0 and more parameters with large values.

    ℹ️ Note
    L2 regularization induces Gaussian prior on the value of β.

    • L1 regularization also can be used to select features:

      • Construct a lot of features and add to feature map.

      • Use L1 regularization regression to select subset of features. i.e., coefficient βj≠0→ feature j is selected.

      • Remove unselected features from the feature map and run vanilla linear regression. (Optional)

    📘 Important
    For L1 regularized linear regression, gradient descent still works, but there is no closed-form solution.

Summary

ℹ️ Note
Just to remind, for a ML Design, it has hypothesis class (corresponding to the red part) + loss function (corresponding to the blue part) + optimizer (corresponding to the green part)

Logistic Regression

  • Input: Z={(x1,y1),(x2,y2),…,(xn,yn)},yi∈{0,1} (Binary Classification)

  • Output: yi≈fβ(xi)

  • Hypothesis class (model family): linear functions

  • Loss Function: MSE loss

  • Optimizer: Gradient Descent

Linear Regression to Binary Classification

yi=βTxi→{Predict yi=class 1 if βTxi≥0Predict yi=class 0 if βTxi<0

From continuous to discrete.

Neural Networks

  • Representation learning: Automatically lean good features for tasks.

    e.g, recognizing casts in photos. Instead of people manually listing features (like “furry tails”), the neural network can lean these useful clues directly from data.

  • Deep learning: Learn multiple levels of representation at increasing levels of complexity.

    Thinking it as a tower of understanding.

    The bottom layer learns simple patterns. The middle layer combines these simple patterns into more complex shapes. The top layer combine those complex shapes into whole object.

A Framework Uniting Many ML Hypothesis Class

  • Linear Regression

    • No bias (actually, there is a bias in input)

    • With bias

  • Logistic Regression

    • Binary

    • Multiclass

💡 Tip
Q: Is the hypothesis class larger?

A: No. Because a 2-layers network can be written as:

fBL=2,BL=1(x)=B1×d′L=2Bd′×dL=1xd×1=W1×dxd×1

​ Thus, the set of functions expressible by the 2-layer network is exactly the same as the set expressible by a single linear lager. So the hypothesis class is neither larger nor smaller.

But, after adding non-linear activation functions, the hypothesis class is changed.

where $g(\cdot) $ is non-linear activation function. Then the function is changed to:

fBL=2,BL=1(x)=B1×d′L=2Bd′×dL=1xd×1=W1×dxd×1→B1×d′L=2g(Bd′×dL=1xd×1)

  • An Example

    The input feature x=(x1,x2) is not easy to separate. After the first layer BL=1 and tanh activation, we can get the following:

    Now, it is much easy to separate red points and blue points. So, the first layers learned a good features from data like manual feature map engineering.

Neural Net Building Blocks and Notation

In neural nets, it is conventional to refer to parameters as “weights” and denote them as W, w etc. rather than the \Beta, β etc.

Basic Structure

Neutral networks are made up of nodes or units, connected by links. Links have associated parameters (weights).

Neural Network’s layers are generally homogenous, because within a single layer, the computational units typically share uniform structure, operation rules, or parameter types.

Units are organized into layers:

We can create a deeper network by stacking layer on itself.

Forward Propagation

The output of the first layer is a1=g1(W(1)xi+b(1)).

The output of the second layer is g2(W(2)a1+b(2))=g2(W(2)g1(W(1)xi+b(1))+b(2)) .

The final output is $ f(x_{i})=g^{(o)}\big (… g_{2}\big (W^{(2)}\big (g_{1}\big (W{(1)}x_{i}+b{(1)}\big )\big )+b^{(2)}\big )+\cdots b^{(o)} \big )$.

So, each result is computed based on the previous layer’s output.

Learnable parameter is W=[W(1),b(1),…,W(o),b(o)].

Backward Pass

Loss functions

Same as single-layer models like linear and logistic regression

  • Regression:

    • MSE

  • Classficiation:

    • Negative log-likelihood

      • Binary cross entropy for binary classification.

        ℹ️ Note
        Binary cross entropy is −[y∗log(p^)+(1−y)∗log(1−p^)].

      • Softmax loss for multi-class classification.

Optimizer

Objective function:

W∗=argW⁡minL(W;Z)

💡 Tip
Q: Don’t I have to optimize differently for different L(⋅) ?

A: No, just use gradient descent. It is most general optimization approach.

Q: But what if L(⋅) is non-convex in W?

A: It almost surely is. Do gradient descent anyway. Just make sure everything is differentiable.

Back Propagation

Back propagation is for adjusting W. It is based on gradient descent.

Wt+1=Wt−α∇W=Wt−αdL(fW(x),y)dW|W=WtdL(fW(x),y)dW=[dL(fW(x),y)d[W(1),b(1)],dL(fW(x),y)d[W(2),b(2)],…,dL(fW(x),y)d[W(o),b(o)]]

It is difficult to calculate this formula by hand, let alone loss function with regularization term.

There is a much easier way to calculate it using computational graph based on chain rule.

Computational Graph

Let us take h=log⁡(x1x2)sin⁡(x2) as an example.

  • Break down function computation into:

    • Data: Input, Output and Intermediate

    • Operator: Addition, Multiplication

      Requirements for each operator: Forward + Backward.

To update parameters x1,x2, we need to compute the gradient, which is [∂L∂x1,∂L∂x2].

Consider we use MSE loss, then, we get that: L=(y−w)2.

Thus,

∂L∂w=−2(y−w)

If y=3,w=5, then we get a numerical result ∂L∂w=−2(3−5)=4.

Then, according to the chain rule, we can get the expression of ∂L∂x1,∂L∂x2:

{∂L∂x1=∂L∂w∂w∂y1∂y1∂a∂a∂x1∂L∂x2=∂L∂w∂w∂y2∂y2∂x2+∂L∂w∂w∂y1∂y1∂a∂a∂x2

📘 Important
There two paths from w to x2 in the backward graph. The first is w→y1→a→x2 and the second is w→y2→x2.

Since w=y1y2, then we can get:

∂w∂y1=y2,∂w∂y2=y1

Since y1=log⁡(a), then, we can get:

∂y1∂a=1a

Since y2=sin⁡(x2), we can get that:

∂y2∂x2=cos⁡(x2)

Since a=x1x2, we can get that:

∂a∂x1=x2,∂a∂x2=x1

Thus, we can get the final expression of ∂L∂x1,∂L∂x2:

{∂L∂x1=4∗y2∗1a∗x2∂L∂x2=4∗y1∗cos(x2)+4∗y2∗1a∗x1

Since we have got the value of y1,y2,a,x1,x2 from forward propagation, we can get the value of ∂L∂x1,∂L∂x2.

You also can get an practical example in L09.pdf - page 13

Computing Rules for Each Nodes

The gradient of each node’s outputs is with respect to its input.

  • Forward pass: y=f(x)

    For this kind of node (single input, single output), the backward pass is:

    ∇xL=∇xf(x)∇yL

  • Forward pass: y=f(x1,x2)

    For this kind of node (multiple input, single output), the backward pass is:

    {∇x1L=∇x1f(x)∇yL∇x2L=∇x2f(x)∇yL

  • Forward pass: y=f(x1,x2)

    For this kind of node (multiple input, multiple output), the backward pass is:

    {∇x1L=∇x1f(x)∇yL∇x2L=∇x2f(x)∇yL

    It is very interesting that we sum the gradient of L from the two paths. The reason for that is as follow.

    Let us consider L=h(g1(y),g2(y)). Then, ΔL is

    ΔL≈∂h∂g1Δg1+∂h∂g2Δg2

    Since

    g1′(y)=limΔy→0Δg1Δy⇒Δg1≈g1′(y)Δy

    we can get:

    Δg1≈g1′(y)Δy,Δg2≈g2′(y)Δy

    Then,

    ΔL≈(∂h∂g1g1′(y)+∂h∂g2g2′(y))Δy

    Thus,

    dLdy=∂h∂g1g1′(y)+∂h∂g2g2′(y)

Let us back to Neural Network, each layer can be seen as a node in a computational graph that receives two kinds of inputs:

  1. previous activations, or to say previous layer’s output

  2. parameters

and each node (layer) emits one output.

Let us take Layer 4 as an example to analyze the gradient descent in the Neural Network.

The input of Layer 4 is a3 (the output of Layer 3) and W(4),b(4). The output of Layer 4 is a3. Thus, it is a multiple input single output node (i.e., y=f(x1,x2)).

Thus,

{∇a3L=∇a3f(x)∇a4L∇W(4),b(4)L=∇W(4),b(4)f(x)∇a4L

In practice, we often separate gradient computation and update.

📘 Important
Neural Network layers must:

  • Perform differentiable operations, thus gradient exist.

The Neural Net Toolbox

Optimization

  • Challenges

    • Local minima
    • Saddle points
    • Ill-conditioning
    • Exploding/ Vanishing gradients
Mini-Batch SGD

For the formal SGD, we calculate the gradient using one sampel at each step until traversing the entire dataset (epoch). But, in the mini-batch SGD, we calculate the gradient using a group of samples at each step until traversing the entire dataset (epoch).

flowchart TD
    A[Initialize Weights W] --> B[Shuffle Dataset]
    B --> C{Pass Over Full Dataset?}
    C -- No --> D[Get Next Batch X_t, y_t]
    D --> E[Compute Gradient dL/dW]
    E --> F[Update W: W_new = W_old - \alpha * dL/dW]
    F --> C
    C -- Yes --> G[End Epoch]

A group of samples can give a more representative result of the loss with respect to the full dataset

Momentum Gradient Descent

In momentum GD, we induces ρ. It is a momentum variable (inertia) that remembers past update. So, we need to update momentum and parameters simultaneously.

Update momentum:

ρ=μρ−α∇W|W=Wt

where μ is a hyperparameter, which should be tried around 0.9 or 0.99.

Update parameters:

Wt+1=Wt+ρ

  • Red arrow : −α∇W|W=Wt

  • Green arrow: μρ

  • Purple arrow: ρ

Momentum GD uses both the current gradient and history of past gradients (via ρ), so it is less affected by “irregular bumps” in the loss function.

  • Nesterov Momentum

    Update momentum:

    ρ=μρ−α∇W|W=Wt+μρ

    That is different with normal momentum. It adds a “lookahead step”. It compute the gradient not at the current position Wt, but at the position you’d be in after applying the momentum from the previous step Wt+μρ.

    Update parameters:

    Wt+1=Wt+ρ

    That is similar with normal momentum GD.

    • Green arrow: represents the inertia from past updates (μρ).

    • Red arrow: Instead computing the gradient at the current red dot, Nesterov first moves along the green momentum step to a new temporary position, then computes the gradient there. The red arrow is the gradient at that “lookahead” position. (−α∇W|W=Wt+μρ)

    • Purple arrow: The final update.

    Nesterov momentum can avoid overshooting, because Nesterov momentum peeks ahead to the next position, adjust the gradient there, and updates more precisely.

Adaptive Learing Rates

  • Adagrad

    Adjusts the learning rate for each parameter based on all past gradients of that parameter.

    Accumulate squared gradients:

    G=G+(∇W|W=Wt)2

    Update parameters:

    Wt+1=Wt−α∇W|W=WtG=Wt−αG∇W|W=Wt

    If a parameter has large gradients in the past (G is large), its learning rate is scaled down. If a parameter has small gradients in the past, its learning rate is scaled up.

    It is great for sparse data (e.g., NLP), but learning rate decays too much over time, which can stall training.

  • RMSProp

    Is based on Adagrad, but give more weight to recent gradients.

    G=λG+(1−λ)(∇W|W=Wt)2Wt+1=Wt−α∇W|W=WtG

    It is more stable than Adagrad, especially for long training runs.

  • Adam (Most common)

    Combines RMSProp and Momentum. It is with both the first and second moments of the gradients.

    ℹ️ Note
    Moment is a term in statistic. First moment (一阶矩) is Mean. Second moment (二阶矩) is Variance-like term

    Updating of G1 is pretty similar with momentum. That can speed up convergence.

    G1=λ1G1+(1−λ1)(∇W|W=Wt)

    Updating of G2 is pretty similar with RMSProp. That can adapt learning rate.

    G2=λ2G2+(1−λ2)(∇W|W=Wt)2Wt+1=Wt−αG1G2

    Adam can let model converge fast and stably.

ℹ️ Note
Common use: Adam > Momentum GD > RMSProp

Set the Learning Rate

Dropping the learning rate every time validation loss stagnates is extremely useful for training.

Activation Functions

Thresholding functions mimic how biological neurons work: a neuron “fires” if input exceed a threshold, otherwise it silences. But they are not differentiable everywhere (only at threshold). This makes backpropagation impossible. Several Activation functions address this by softening the threshold functions into a continuous, differentiable curve.

  • Sigmoid

    S(x)=11+e−x=exex+1

    The derivative is: S(x)(1−S(x)).

  • Tanh

    tanh⁡(x)=ex−e−xex+e−x=2sigmoid(2x)−1

    The derivative is tanh′⁡(x)=ex+e−xex−e−x

For Sigmoid and tanh, when the absolute value of input is pretty large (e.g, 10000 or -100000), the gradient vanishes. Then the update becomes very slow.

The gradient of Sigmoid and tanh are non-zero in a narrow regions, approx. zero everywhere else.

  • Relu

    f(x)=max(0,x)

    The derivative is:

    f′(x)={1,x≥00,x<0

    • Pros:

      • Solve the problem of vanishing gradients, when the input value is positive.
      • It is easy to calculate.

    • Cons:

      • The gradients is 0, when the input value is negative.

  • Leaky Relu (Parametrix ReLU: PReLU)

    f(x)=max(ax,x)

    The derivative is:

    f′(x)={1,x≥0a,x<0

ℹ️ Note
ReLU and relative activation functions (LeakyReLU, PReLU) are good starting choices of activation functions at the hidden layers of the network. Using thoes functions let training deep nets faster.

Managing Weights

Initialization

  • Zero Initialization

    ⚠️ Warning
    Do Not initialize weights to all zeros.

    If all weights W in a layer are initialized to 0. Then, every neuron computes the same output for any input X: zi=Wi∗X+bi=0∗X+0=0 (for all neurons i).

    In the forward propagation, because each neuron has same weights and bias, they produce same output. In the backward propagation, because the gradient for each neurons depends only on its output and upstream gradient from the next layer, their gradients are also identical.

    In the parameter update, since gradients are all identical and Wold=0, Wnew remains identical across neurons.

    It is equivalent to just having 1 unit per layer → Symmetry (must be broken!)

  • Kaiming Initialization

    Designed for ReLU.

    Weights are initialized from a normal distribution $W_\mathrm{layer}\sim\mathcal{N}\left(0,\frac{2}{D_\mathrm{in}}\right) $, where $D_{in} = $ number of inputs to the layer.

  • Xavier Initialization

    Designed for tanh.

    Weights are initialized from a normal distribution Wlayer∼N(0,1Din+Dout), where Din = inputs to the layer, Dout = output to the layer.

  • Bias Initialization

    Initialize the biases to be all zeros.

ℹ️ Note
Recommend Kaiming or Xavier

Batch Normalization

Covariate shift: As layers 1,2,…,l-1 learn, the distribution of inputs to layer l are shifting.

Obviously, covariant shift slows down learning.

To solve this problem, we should standardize the activations of each layer, so that they are always in N(0,1).

Standardization is differentiable. So gradient descent still works.

We can compute mean and std (standard deviation) over mini-batch.

Batch Normalization can be applied before or after activation layer. (i.e., RuLU(BN(Wx)) or BN(RuLU(Wx))).

ℹ️ Note
Recommend BN after activation → BN(RuLU(Wx))

Regularization

  • L2 regularization

    Add λ2∥W∥22 to loss function. It is equivalent to decay weight at every update W=W−λW. (so, it is also called weight decay)

  • L1 regularization

    Add λ|W| to loss fucntion.

⚠️ Warning
Do Not regularize bias term

ℹ️ Note
Recommend L2 + Dropout

Dropout

Randomly drop a fraction p (usually 0.5) of the units in a layer.

There are three intuitions that can help to explain why does dropout work?

  • Intuition 1: Noise-robustness to missing information.

    During training, Dropout randomly “drops out” (disables) some neurons’ outputs. This forces the network to learn to make predictions even when part of the input information is missing.

    Just as humans can recognize objects even if parts are obscured (e.g., a partially hidden cat), the network becomes robust to noise or incomplete inputs — it doesn’t rely on any single neuron or feature to make decisions.

  • Intuition 2: Units must work with diverse co-units (leading to disentangled features).

    Dropout’s randomness means a neuron never relies on specific partner neurons (since those partners might be dropped out in any iteration).

    This forces each neuron to learn features that work with many different sets of “companion” neurons (instead of relying on a fixed group).

  • Intuition 3: Training a “random subset” of networks (implicit ensemble learning)

    When Dropout is applied to a layer with N neurons, each training iteration effectively trains a slightly different subnetwork — chosen randomly from 2N possible subnetworks (since each neuron has two states: “active” or “dropped out”).

    For example, a layer with 100 neurons has 2100possible subnetworks — a huge number. Most subnetworks are never trained in full, and each subnetwork only gets one update per appearance.

    However, all these subnetworks share weights: Updating weights for one subnetwork indirectly updates weights for all subnetworks that share those weights.

    This mirrors ensemble learning (e.g., bagging): Instead of training one large model, Dropout trains thousands of tiny subnetworks, and testing (with all neurons active) acts like an “ensemble” of these subnetworks — improving generalization.

During the training, we can turn on the dropout to improve the generalization. But, in the testing, we should turn off the dropout. However, now, the output strength of each neuron is twice of what it is in training (consider p = 0.5. In the training, each neuron has 50% contribution to the output. But, in the testing, because the dropout is switched off, each neuron has 100% contribution to the output.).

Thus, we should divide outgoing weights by 2 (or 1/dropout). This approximates the “average” prediction of all possible sub-models created during training.

Managing Training

Monitor your validation losses, and stop training your network when they start rising. Can be thought of as a simple and really efficient way to introduce regularization.

Data Augmentation

It is often used when you know that your output is robust to some transformations of your data.

For the pictures, you can rotate, shift, flip, crop and combine them. For the language, you can substitute synonyms.

Hyperparameter Optimization

  • Keep the number of hyperparameters as small as possible.

    If your computation budget lets you optimize only one hyperparameter, let it be the learning rate.

  • Parallelize search across many machines.

  • Record hyperparameters of all runs carefully.

  • Use the same random init for all hyperparameters.

    That means initializing the weight of the model with same random seed when testing different combinations of hyperparameters, because the randomness of weight may affect the result.

  • For 2 or 3 hyperparameters, do a systematic “grid search”

ℹ️ Note
For high-dimensional hyperparameter spaces (>3 hyperparameters), random search is more efficient than grid search. It finds better models with fewer training runs by focusing on impactful hyperparameters.

Coarse-to-fine Search

  1. First, search over a large (coarse) range of hyperparameters to identify a “promising region” with good performance.

  2. Then, narrow the search window (to a finer scale) around this promising region and repeat — refining the search to find the exact optimal hyperparameters.

If best results are not at the boundaries of the current window,
center a smaller window on the best hyperparameters found so far, and repeat the search (to refine the search in this more focused region).

If best results are near the boundaries of the current window,
shift the window to center on the best hyperparameters, then repeat (to ensure the optimal value isn’t “cut off” by the window’s edge).

There also an advanced tip: Bayesian Optimization. (Todo)

Cross-validation vs a Single Validation Set

Full k-fold cross-validation might be computationally too expensive. Thus, a single large held-out validation set suffices.

K-Nearest Neighbors

In K-Nearest Neighbors, we don’t train a model based on the data. On the contrary, the data is the model.

According to the distribution of red points and blue points, we can explicitly find out two different areas. Each represents either Large or Medium. If a new point has been placed “Large” area, nearing by red points, it has a high probability to be “Large”. Same does “Medium”

  • KNN Classification: To predict category label y of a new point x

    • Find “k nearest neighbors”.
    • Assign the majority label.

  • KNN Regression: To predict value y of a new point x

    • Find “k nearest neighbors”.
    • Average the values associated with the neighbors.

Thus, if you change the k, the prediction result may change.

The Definition of “Nearest”

Consider we are calculating the distance between x1,x2.

  • ℓ1 distance

    (∑j|x1j−x2j|1)11=∑j|x1j−x2j|

  • ℓ2 distance

    (∑j|x1j−x2j|2)12

    Euclidean distance

  • ℓ∞ distance

    (∑j|x1j−x2j|→∞)→0=maxj(|x1j−x2j|)

    Why? Todo

Different distance produce different outcomes.

Let us consider k= 1, then

“Non-parametric” Machine Learning Approches

💡 Tip
Q: In linear regression / logistic regression / neural networks, what do we need to make predictions?

A: Parameters or weights

For the KNN model, there are implicit parameters, which is the full training dataset.

Thus there is no explicit training phase. The moment we have the dataset, we are ready to produce predictions for new input data.

⚠️ Warning
Dataset preprocessing phase that may be thought of as training.

Hyperparameters in KNN

  • Choice of distance function

    Most of time, we choose ℓp=2,1,\infin distance. But, sometimes an ℓp distance after transforming inputs x to some f(x).

  • Choice of k

    Small value of k means model may be easily affected by noisy data. Large value of k makes it difficult to model sharp changes in the true function. For binary classification, usually an odd number to avoid ties.

💡 Tip
Q: What functions can k-NN classifiers / regressors represent? Or perhaps easier to think about: what functions can k-NN models not represent?

A: k-NN models are only limited in expressivity by the training data, so with the right training dataset, k-NN models can represent any function.
